data.title: LOUIS, DUKE OF BURGUNDY French son of Louis de France

Louis, Duke of Burgundy

LOUIS, DUKE OF BURGUNDY - French son of Louis de France and later Grand-Dauphin to Louis XIV (his Grandfather) Date: 1682 - 1712

Mary Evans Picture Library makes available wonderful images created for people to enjoy over the centuries

Media ID 14274728

© Mary Evans Picture Library

1682 1712 Burgundy Dauphin Grandfather

EDITORS COMMENTS

This striking portrait captures the young and ambitious Louis, Duke of Burgundy (1682-1712), the eldest son of Louis, Duke of Burgundy and Anne Marie Louise d'Orléans. Born into the French royal family, Louis was the grandson of King Louis XIV and held the title of Grand Dauphin from 1683 until his father's death in 1711. The Duke of Burgundy was known for his military prowess and political acumen. He served as a general in the War of the Spanish Succession and played a significant role in the diplomatic negotiations that followed. His marriage to Maria Anna of Austria in 1685 was a strategic alliance aimed at strengthening the House of Bourbon's position in Europe. Despite his impressive military and political achievements, Louis' reign as Dauphin was marked by intrigue and power struggles. He was a favorite of his grandfather, King Louis XIV, but his relationship with the regent, Philippe II, Duke of Orléans, was fraught with tension. The Duke of Burgundy's untimely death in 1712, just a year after his father, left the French succession uncertain and led to the Regency of Philippe II. This portrait, created around 1682, captures the Duke of Burgundy in his prime. He is depicted in the regal attire of the time, with a serious expression and a confident posture. The artist has skillfully captured the young man's strong features and the intensity of his gaze, reflecting his determination and ambition. The portrait is a testament to the Duke of Burgundy's status as a powerful and influential figure in French and European politics during the late 17th and early 18th centuries.
